description.narrative: 103/004 By 2020, the Government and stakeholders in the education and private sectors, at national and subnational level, have increased interest and capacity to expand and deliver quality package of services to keep adolescents in school and/or create alternative pathways for out-of-school adolescent aged 10-18, and build livelihood skills and employability opportunities for youth aged 15 to 24 in emergency and non-emergency situations and urban settings., which contributes to Adolescent Empowerment, Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development, Cross-Sectoral Monitoring, Data And Situation Analyses, Cross-Sectoral Planning And Programme Reviews, Education In Emergencies, Education â€“ General, Equitable Access To Quality Education, Equity â€“ Focus On Girls' And Inclusive Education, Learning And Child-Friendly Schools, Learning Outcomes, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Skills Development. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 3. By 2020, adolescent girls and boys in Bangladesh, especially the most disadvantaged, access and utilize high-quality basic social services in a safe and protected environment, and are resilient and empowered as active agents of change.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 103/004 By 2020, the Government and stakeholders in the education and private sectors, at national and subnational level, have increased interest and capacity to expand and deliver quality package of services to keep adolescents in school and/or create alternative pathways for out-of-school adolescent aged 10-18, and build livelihood skills and employability opportunities for youth aged 15 to 24 in emergency and non-emergency situations and urban settings.

description.narrative: Government and stakeholders adopted an adolescent skills framework as the basis for transforming the education system and the provision of skills for adolescents. Increased understanding and capacity of NCTB resulted in the country's first national curriculum framework for pre-primary to secondary, with skills embedded. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2019

title.narrative: Private sector organizations that are engaged in UNICEF / ILO supported initiatives relating to Youth Skills and Employability
Adolescents aged 15 to 18 years accessing secondary education
System Strengthening - Skills - Community engagement support the mainstreaming of skills development within the national system - score (1-4), see guidance
Life skills and citizenship education embedded in the policy and curriculum frameworks - score (1-4), see guidance
Adolescents aged 15 to 18 years and youth aged 19 to 24 years accessing vocational skills training
Secondary school aged out of school children in the reporting year accessing formal or non-formal education with support of the UNICEF programme
Service Delivery - Schools that have included life skills and citizenship education in their school plans with UNICEF support
